questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with numbness and tingling in the lateral aspect of his forearm and thumb after a fall. Upon examination, the physician notes that the sensation is decreased in a specific area corresponding to a dermatome. Which of the following dermatomes is likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) C6

Explanation:

C6 covers the lateral aspect of the forearm and the thumb(1st digit). The patient's symptoms of numbness and tingling in this area suggest involvement of the C6 nerve root.

C5 (Option A) dermatome is primarily responsible for sensation over the shoulder and the upper lateral arm, not the forearm or thumb.

 

C7 (Option C) dermatome covers the index finger (2nd digit) to ring finger (4th digit) and the posterior aspect of the forearm, which does not match the patient’s symptoms.

 

C8 (Option D) dermatome includes the medial aspect of the forearm and the little finger (5th digit), which is also not consistent with the presented symptoms.

questions.text: A newborn is delivered with a shoulder dystocia complication. On examination, the infant has paralysis of the arm with the shoulder adducted, the elbow extended, and the forearm pronated. This injury most likely involves which of the following structures?

choices.text: Lower trunk of the brachial plexus
Upper trunk of the brachial plexus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Upper trunk of the brachial plexus

 

Explanation:

The described presentation is consistent with Erb’s palsy, a result of injury to the upper trunk (C5-C6) of the brachial plexus, which occurs at Erb’s point. This injury commonly happens in cases of shoulder dystocia during birth and leads to the "waiter's tip" posture.

 

Erb's Point: Anatomy and Clinical Relevance

  • Location:
    • Situated in the posterior triangle of the neck, where the upper trunk of the brachial plexus divides.
  • Brachial Plexus Formation:
    • The upper trunk is formed by the union of C5 and C6 ventral rami.
  • Posterior Triangle of the Neck:
    • Brachial plexus trunks emerge between the anterior and middle scalene muscles.
    • Contains structures like the subclavian artery and scalene muscles.

Clinical Significance of Erb's Point:

Feature

Description

Anatomical Role

Upper trunk divides into anterior and posterior divisions

Clinical Importance

Injuries to this area can cause Erb's palsy with specific motor/sensory deficits

Erb's Palsy

Results from damage to the upper trunk, leading to weakness in the upper limb, waiter-tip posture.

Lower trunk of the brachial plexus (Option A): Injury to the lower trunk would cause Klumpke’s palsy, affecting the hand muscles, not the arm posture described here.

Radial nerve (Option B) injury typically causes wrist drop, not the characteristic arm posture described in Erb’s palsy.

Median nerve (Option D) injury leads to weakness in forearm flexion and the thenar muscles, not the upper limb weakness seen in this case.

questions.text: A newborn presents with weakness in the right arm after a difficult vaginal delivery. The arm is limp and hangs by the side, with the forearm pronated and the hand facing inward in a "waiter's tip" position. The infant has difficulty with shoulder abduction and elbow flexion. Which of the following nerve roots are most likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) C5 and C6

 

Explanation:

C5 and C6 involvement is typical in Erb's palsy, causing weakness in muscles responsible for shoulder abduction, external rotation, elbow flexion, and forearm supination.

Erb's Palsy:

  • Erb-Duchenne palsy results from damage to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus (C5 and C6 nerve roots).
  • Mechanism of Injury:
    • Occurs due to traction or stretching of the neck during childbirth (shoulder dystocia) or traumatic separation of the head and shoulder.

Anatomical Structures Involved:

Structure

Description

Brachial Plexus

Formed by ventral rami of C5-T1 spinal nerves

Upper Trunk

Union of C5 and C6 ventral rami

Erb’s Point

Located in the posterior triangle of the neck, where the upper trunk divides into anterior and posterior divisions

Clinical Presentation:

  • Muscle Weakness/ Paralysis:
    • Shoulder Abduction: Affected (supraspinatus, deltoid)
    • External Rotation: Affected (infraspinatus, teres minor)
    • Elbow Flexion: Affected (biceps brachii, brachialis)
    • Forearm Supination: Affected (biceps brachii)
  • Arm Position:
    • Limp arm by the side, forearm pronated, hand inward ("waiter’s tip" position).
  • Sensory Deficits
    • Numbness or tingling along the lateral arm, forearm, and hand, corresponding to C5 and C6 dermatomes.

Associated Findings:

Condition

Description

Horner's Syndrome

Involvement of T1 nerve root, indicating a more extensive injury

Skeletal Abnormalities

Bone deformities (e.g., glenoid dysplasia, clavicular shortening) due to muscle imbalance

 

C7 and C8 (Option B): Injuries here would affect the triceps and finger extension, not the typical presentation seen in Erb's palsy.

C8 and T1 (Option C): Damage here leads to Klumpke’s palsy, affecting hand muscles and causing a "claw hand" deformity.

C3 and C4 (Option D) nerve roots contribute to the phrenic nerve and control the diaphragm, not the arm.

questions.text: A newborn presents with weakness in the hand following a difficult delivery. Examination reveals a claw hand deformity characterized by hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion at the interphalangeal joints. Sensory loss is noted along the ulnar aspect of the forearm and hand. Which of the following is the most likely nerve root involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) T1

 

Explanation:

The given findings are associated with Klumpke’s paralysis. T1 is the main nerve root involved in Klumpke's paralysis, leading to the characteristic claw hand deformity and sensory loss along the ulnar border of the forearm and hand.

Klumpke’s Paralysis:

Aspect

Details

Site of Injury

Lower trunk of the brachial plexus

Cause of Injury

Undue arm abduction (e.g., clutching after a fall)

Birth injury

Nerve Roots Involved

Primarily T1, partially C8
  • Muscles Affected:
    • Intrinsic muscles of the hand (T1)
    • Ulnar flexors of the wrist and fingers (C8)
  • Hand Deformity
    • Claw hand: Unopposed action of long flexors and extensors
      • Hyperextension at metacarpophalangeal joints
      • Flexion at interphalangeal joints
  • Disabilities Associated:
    • Complete claw hand
    • Cutaneous anesthesia and analgesia along the ulnar border of forearm and hand
    • Horner’s Syndrome (if T1 injured near sympathetic ganglion)
      • Symptoms: ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis, enophthalmos, loss of ciliospinal reflex
    • Vasomotor Changes
      • Warmer, drier skin in the sensory loss area due to arteriolar dilation and lack of sweating
    • Trophic Changes
      • Long-term paralysis results in dry, scaly skin, brittle nails, and atrophy of finger pulp

C5 (Option A) is involved in upper trunk injuries, not Klumpke’s paralysis.

 

C7 (Option B) does not play a primary role in the claw hand deformity associated with Klumpke’s paralysis.

 

C8 (Option C): While C8 is involved, the predominant nerve root affected in Klumpke’s paralysis is T1.

questions.text: Which of the following gives rise to the bones and connective tissues of the limb?

choices.text: The parietal (somatic) layer of lateral plate mesoderm

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The parietal (somatic) layer of lateral plate mesoderm

 

Explanation:

The parietal (somatic) layer of the lateral plate mesoderm forms the mesenchymal core of the limb bud, which will differentiate into the bones and connective tissues of the upper limb.

Development of the Upper Limb:

  • The upper limb bud appears around the end of the 4th week of development.
  • These buds form as outpocketings from the lateral body wall.
  • The Mesenchymal Core of the limb buds is derived from the parietal layer of lateral plate mesoderm, which later gives rise to bones and connective tissues.
  • The limb bud is covered by a layer of ectoderm, which thickens at the distal end to form the apical ectodermal ridge (AER). 

Period of Gestation

Event

4th Week

Appearance of the upper limb bud

6th Week

Formation of hand plate and initiation of chondrification.

7th Week

Limb rotation and further cartilage development.

12th Week

Primary ossification centers in long bones.

Intermediate mesoderm (Option A) forms structures like the urogenital system.

Paraxial mesoderm (Option C) forms somites, which give rise to skeletal muscles and parts of the vertebrae.

Neural crest cells (Option D) contribute to the peripheral nervous system, but not to the bones and connective tissues of the limbs.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with numbness and tingling along the lateral aspect of his forearm and thumb following a fall on his outstretched arm. Which dermatome is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) C6

Explanation:

The C6 dermatome covers the lateral aspect of the forearm, the thumb, and part of the index finger. Numbness or tingling in this area, suggests involvement of the C6 dermatome.

 

Dermatomes of the Upper Limb:

Spinal Nerve Root

Dermatome (Sensory Area)

C5 (Option A ruled out)

Lateral upper arm, over the deltoid

C6 (Option B)

Lateral forearm and thumb(1st digit)

C7 (Option C ruled out)

Index finger (2nd digit) to Ring finger (4th digit)

C8 (Option D ruled out)

Medial forearm, little finger (5th digit)

T1

Medial arm and elbow

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with difficulty extending his elbow after a recent injury. On examination, you notice weakness in elbow extension and diminished triceps reflex. Sensory examination is normal. Which myotome is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) C7

Explanation:

The C7 myotome innervates the triceps muscle, which is responsible for elbow extension.

 

Myotomes of the Upper Limb:

Spinal Nerve Root

Myotome (Motor Function)

C5 (Option A ruled out)

Shoulder abduction (deltoid), elbow flexion (biceps)

C6 (Option B ruled out)

Elbow flexion, wrist extension (biceps, wrist extensors)

C7 (Option C)

Elbow extension (triceps), wrist flexion (wrist flexors)

C8 (Option D ruled out)

Finger flexion, thumb extension (finger flexors, intrinsic hand muscles)

T1

Finger abduction and adduction (intrinsic hand muscles, interossei)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with weakness in the upper limb following a fall on his shoulder. Physical examination reveals impaired movement in the extensor muscles of the arm. Injury to which part of the brachial plexus is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Middle trunk, posterior division

Explanation:

The posterior divisions of the brachial plexus innervate the extensor muscles of the upper limb. The middle trunk is a direct continuation of the C7 ventral ramus and its posterior division supplies the extensor muscles.

Brachial Plexus Trunks: 

  • Formation:
    • Five ventral rami (C5–T1) form three trunks.
    • Upper Trunk: Formed by C5 and C6.
    • Middle Trunk: Continuation of C7.
    • Lower Trunk: Formed by C8 and T1, crossing over the first rib.
  • Location:
    • Trunks emerge between anterior and middle scalene muscles.
    • Positioned anteriorly to each other, with the subclavian artery running anteromedially.
  • Divisions:
    • Each trunk divides into:
      • Posterior Divisions: Innervate extensor muscles.
      • Anterior Divisions: Innervate flexor muscles.
  • Clinical Relevance:
    • Trunks, especially the upper trunk, can be palpated in the supraclavicular fossa.
    • Important for procedures like nerve blocks.

Brachial Plexus Trunk Formation and Divisions:

Trunk

Formation

Divisions

Upper Trunk

Union of C5 and C6 rami

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option A ruled out)

Posterior: Extensor muscles

Middle Trunk


 

Continuation of C7

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option B ruled out)

Posterior: Extensor muscles (Option C)

Lower Trunk

Union of C8 and T1 rami

Anterior: Flexor muscles (Option A ruled out)

Passing over first rib

Posterior: Extensor muscles

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motorcycle accident. He complains of severe pain and weakness in his right arm. On examination, there is loss of sensation in the right shoulder and upper arm with weakness in shoulder abduction and elbow flexion. Which of the following is the most likely type of brachial plexus lesion in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Closed traction injury

 

Explanation:

Closed traction injury commonly occurs due to violent forces, such as those experienced in high-speed accidents, which stretch or tear the nerves of the brachial plexus. The symptoms of pain, weakness, and sensory loss in this patient are consistent with this type of lesion.

Brachial Plexus Lesions:

  • Damage or dysfunction in the brachial plexus, a nerve network from the spinal cord controlling shoulder, arm, and hand functions.
  • Causes of Brachial Plexus Lesions include: Trauma, birth trauma, tumors, radiation therapy

Types of Lesions:

Type

Description

Closed Traction Lesions (Option C)

Result from forces that stretch or tear nerves, often in high-impact incidents like accidents.

Intradural Ruptures/Avulsions (Option A ruled out)

Nerve roots torn from the spinal cord; harder to treat than other injuries.

Compression Injuries (Option B ruled out)

Caused by pressure on the brachial plexus, including:

Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (TOS): Compression between the clavicle and first rib.

Hematoma: Internal bleeding compressing the plexus.

Anomalous Muscles/Structures: Extra anatomical features causing compression.

Iatrogenic Injury: Damage during medical procedures. (Option D ruled out)

Symptoms:

Symptom

Description

Sensory Changes

Numbness, tingling, pain, or burning in the shoulder, arm, or hand.

Motor Weakness

Difficulty moving the shoulder, arm, or hand, with specific weakness patterns aiding localization.

Autonomic Dysfunction

Changes in sweating, skin temperature, or blood flow in the affected limb.

Diagnosis:

  • Physical Exam: Assessing sensation, muscle strength, and reflexes.
  • Imaging Studies: X-rays, CT scans, or MRI to identify fractures, dislocations, or tumors.
  • Electrodiagnostic Tests: Nerve conduction studies (NCS) and electromyography (EMG) to assess nerve function and damage extent.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with weakness in elbow flexion and loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of his forearm. Which of the following nerves is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Musculocutaneous nerve

 

Explanation:

The musculocutaneous nerve innervates the biceps brachii and brachialis muscles, responsible for elbow flexion. It also provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the forearm.

Brachial Plexus:

  • Brachial plexus: Nerve network for upper limb motor and sensory function.
  • Origins: From ventral rami of C5, C6, C7, C8, and T1 spinal nerves.
  • Structure: Roots → trunks → divisions → cords.
  • Function: Specific nerves innervate muscles and skin in the arm and hand.

Brachial Plexus Cords:

Cord

Formation

Lateral Cord

Anterior divisions of upper and middle trunks

Posterior Cord

All three posterior divisions

Medial Cord

Anterior division of lower trunk (sometimes middle trunk)

Innervations by Cord:

Cord

Nerve

Motor Innervation

Sensory Innervation

Lateral Cord

Musculocutaneous (C5, C6, C7) (Option B)

Biceps brachii, brachialis, coracobrachialis

Lateral forearm

Lateral Root of Median (C5, C6, C7)

Contributes to median nerve (primarily hand muscles)

Contributes to sensory innervation of the hand

Posterior Cord

Axillary (C5, C6) (Option A ruled out)

Deltoid, teres minor

Lateral shoulder

Radial (C5, C6, C7, C8, T1) (Option C ruled out)

Triceps, brachioradialis, wrist and finger extensors, supinator

Posterior arm, forearm, dorsolateral hand

Upper Subscapular (C5, C6)

Subscapularis

None

Thoracodorsal (C6, C7, C8)

Latissimus dorsi

None

Lower Subscapular (C5, C6)

Subscapularis, teres major

None

Medial Cord

Ulnar (C8, T1) (Option D ruled out)

Flexor carpi ulnaris, flexor digitorum profundus (medial half), most intrinsic hand muscles

Medial hand, little finger, medial half of ring finger

Median (C5, C6, C7, C8, T1)

Pronators, wrist/finger flexors (except those supplied by ulnar), thenar muscles

Palmar hand (thumb, index, middle, lateral half of ring finger)

Medial Pectoral (C8, T1)

Pectoralis major, pectoralis minor

None

Medial Cutaneous Nerve of Arm (C8, T1)

None

Medial arm

Medial Cutaneous Nerve of Forearm (C8, T1)

None

Medial forearm

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the variations in the prefixed and postfixed brachial plexus?

choices.text: Prefixed brachial plexus is characterized by contributions from C5 to T2.
T2 spinal nerve replaces the usual T1 contribution in postfixed brachial plexus.
Prefixed brachial plexus has an increased contribution from C4 and decreased from T1.
Postfixed brachial plexus is associated with an increased contribution from C3 and C4.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Prefixed brachial plexus has an increased contribution from C4 and decreased from T1.

 

Explanation:

  • A prefixed brachial plexus has an increased contribution from C4 and decreased from T1 while a postfixed brachial plexus involves contributions from C6-T2, with diminished input from C5 and increased input from T2.
  • The variations are significant in clinical practice as they can affect the innervation patterns of the upper limb and may impact nerve injury presentations.
 

Prefixed

Postfixed

Nerve root

C4-C8

C6-T2

Shift

Upward shift

Downward shift

C4 contribution

Increased

Nil or minimal

C5 contribution

Normal

Reduced

T1 contribution

Reduced or nil

Normal along with added T2

Risk

No risk of compression

High risk of compression

(Thoracic outlet syndrome)
 


 

Prefixed brachial plexus is characterized by contributions from C5 to T2 (Option A) is incorrect as in a prefixed brachial plexus, the contribution shifts upward, involving C4-C8, not C5 to T2. There is minimal or no input from T1 in a prefixed plexus.

 

T2 spinal nerve replaces the usual T1 contribution in postfixed brachial plexus (Option B) is incorrect as in a postfixed brachial plexus, the contribution extends downward and typically includes C6-T2, but T2 does not replace T1. Instead, T1 remains part of the plexus, and T2 provides an additional contribution.

 

Postfixed brachial plexus is associated with an increased contribution from C3 and C4 (Option D) is incorrect as a postfixed brachial plexus involves a downward shift, resulting in contributions from C6-T2. There is no involvement of C3 and C4, which are part of the cervical plexus, not the brachial plexus.

questions.text: Which part of the brachial plexus does not give off any branches?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Divisions

 

Explanation: The divisions of the brachial plexus (anterior and posterior) act as a passage for nerve fibers to reorganize and form cords but they themselves do not give rise to any branches.

 

Part of brachial plexus

Branches

Roots
  • Dorsal scapular nerve - C5
  • Long thoracic nerve - C5 to C7

Trunks
  • Suprascapular nerve - C5, C6
  • Nerve to subclavius - C5, C6

Division
  • None

Cords
  • Lateral pectoral nerve (Lateral cord: C5-C7)
  • Upper subscapular nerve (Posterior cord: C5, C6)
  • Thoracodorsal nerve (Posterior cord: C6-C8)
  • Lower subscapular nerve (Posterior cord: C5, C6)
  • Medial pectoral nerve (Medial cord: C8, T1)
  • Medial cutaneous nerve of arm (Medial cord: C8, T1)
  • Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm (Medial cord: C8, T1)

Terminal branches
  • Musculocutaneous nerve (Lateral cord, C5-C7)
  • Axillary nerve (Posterior cord, C5, C6)
  • Radial nerve (Posterior cord, C5-T1)
  • Median nerve (Lateral and Medial cords, C5-T1)
  • Ulnar nerve (Medial cord, C8, T1)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the anterior and posterior axial lines is correct?

choices.text: Axial lines form as a result of limb rotational and elongation processes during embryogenesis
Axial lines divide dermatomes that are adjacent in the spinal nerve sequence
Overlapping of nerve supply can overlap across axial lines
Overlapping of Ventral and dorsal axial lines can occur

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Axial lines form as a result of limb rotational and elongation processes during embryogenesis


Explanation : Axial lines are the dividing lines between dermatomes that are not adjacent in the spinal nerve sequence which are formed as a result of limb rotational and elongation processes during embryogenesis.

Axial lines

Axial lines are the dividing lines between dermatomes that are not adjacent in the spinal nerve sequence.

Types

  • Ventral Axial Line (on the anterior surface of the limb).
  • Dorsal Axial Line (on the posterior surface of the limb).

Formation

  • During embryological development, the limbs undergo lateral rotation (upper limb) or medial rotation (lower limb).
  • This rotation creates a spiral arrangement of dermatomes and shifts certain dermatomes distally.
  • Axial lines form as a result of these rotational and elongation processes.

Significance

  • Axial lines are important for understanding nerve injuries and mapping sensory deficits.
  • Across these lines, there is no overlap between dermatomes, so sensory loss in these areas can help pinpoint the exact nerve or spinal segment involved.

Axial lines divide dermatomes that are adjacent in the spinal nerve sequence (Option B): This is incorrect as axial lines do not divide adjacent dermatomes. Instead, they divide dermatomes from non-adjacent spinal nerve roots. Adjacent dermatomes (e.g., C5 and C6) overlap significantly, and no axial line exists between them. For example, the ventral axial line separates C5, C6 from C8, T1, and T2, which are non-adjacent segments.

 

Overlapping of nerve supply can overlap across axial lines (Option C): This is incorrect as one of the defining features of axial lines is that there is no overlap of dermatomes across them. While overlapping of adjacent dermatomes is common elsewhere (e.g., C5 overlaps with C6), this does not happen across axial lines.

 

Overlapping of ventral and dorsal axial lines can occur (Option D): This is incorrect as the ventral and dorsal axial lines are distinct anatomical landmarks and do not overlap. They are located on opposite surfaces of the limb:

  • The ventral axial line is on the anterior (palmar) surface of the limb.
  • The dorsal axial line is on the posterior (dorsal) surface of the limb.
